image.altText: A grey card with the PTV and myki symbols is placed against a card reader which says the card has expired.

items.synopsis: Another company which lost the contract to provide Victoria's public transport ticketing system has called for an urgent review of the tender process, saying it lacked rigour and transparency.

title.children: 'Mistakes have clearly been made': Second letter from failed bidder urges review of Victoria's myki overhaul contract

image.altText: Collins gestures with one hand while speaking at the despatch box in the House of Representatives.

items.synopsis: The federal government has left open the option of pursuing housing options that will be met with less resistance, after failing to pass its signature $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund.

title.children: Housing minister won't rule out dumping signature $10b fund in favour of easier paths to building housing

image.altText: Barbed wire sits above a wire fence, with a bird in the background.

items.synopsis: Victoria'sÂ parole process is set to change so if a murderer is denied parole, they will have to wait at least five years before reapplying. The change comes after campaigning from the families of Paul Denyer's victims.

title.children: Victoria to make it harder for murderers to reapply for parole, after Paul Denyer's request denied

image.altText: An image of the Reserve bank sign in Martin Place, Sydney

items.synopsis: Minutes from this month's RBA board meeting show interest rates were almost kept steady this month.

title.children: Reserve Bank almost left interest rates on hold this month

image.altText: Baby Jarrod at time of second visit to Caboolture hospital in October 2022. The child has a rash around his mouth and face

items.synopsis: Baby Jarrod was in "absolute agony" when his parents took him to the emergency department two days in a row. He only received a diagnosis when his father called in Ryan's Rule.

title.children: Baby in 'absolute agony' turned away days after assurances hospital was providing best possible care

image.altText: A composite image of two men and a woman, separated by paper tears.

items.synopsis: Across Australia, more than 46,000 clients under state control are prevented by law from being identified, but there are growing calls for change. Some say gag laws that were designed to protect vulnerable people are shielding the agencies involved from scrutiny.

title.children: Memories sent to the tip, refused money for Christmas â and all by order of the state

image.altText: A small submersible plunging into the water.

items.synopsis: Deep in the waters of the Atlantic Ocean, a search is underwayÂ for a submersible that was carrying fiveÂ people when itÂ disappeared on an expedition to the wreckage of the Titanic.

title.children: Frantic search as Titanic submersible disappears underwater with five people and 96 hours' oxygen

image.altText: Three people stand in blizzard at Mount Hotham.

items.synopsis: A polar air massÂ sends the mercury plunging over south-easternÂ Australia on Tuesday and Wednesday, while a thick rain band is brewing in the north-west andÂ set to deliver falls across the country by the end of the week.

title.children: South-eastern Australia to shiver through prolonged frosty weather, with 'tropical' rain on the way

image.altText: Black and white photograph of a man playing the guitar with long hair

items.synopsis: Crispin Dye's case which was due to be revisited today at an inquiry has now been delayed after a judge described NSW Police record keeping as "borderline shambolic".

title.children: New evidence about brutal death of AC/DC manager uncovered during gay hate inquiry

image.altText: A sign post with pathways saying Yes and No against a blue sky

items.synopsis: For the first time in 24 years, Australians are heading to the polls to decide on a change to the constitution. Legislation setting up a referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament passed the Senate on Monday, meaning a referendum has to be held before the end of the year.

title.children: It's official â the Voice referendum is happening. Here's what comes next

image.altText: Close up of red and green numbers on ASX board

items.synopsis: The local share market rises to a fresh seven-week high, while the Australian dollar slips after the Reserve Bank releases its June meeting minutes, detailing its worries of inflation becoming entrenched in the economy.

title.children: Minutes show RBA lifted rates on fears of entrenched inflation, Aussie dollar slips

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Bullock says the quick action of monetary and fiscal policy during the COVID-19 pandemic helped to minimise the worst impacts it had on the economy. "Hundreds of thousands of Australians lost their jobs, and an equally large number were stood down or had their hours cut. "This was a time of extreme uncertainty, with a deadly virus threatening peopleâs health and livelihoods and no vaccines in sight. "There were credible projections that the unemployment rate would rise to 15 per cent, and our own forecasts from the time had the unemployment rate remaining high for several years." But she says Australia avoided the prospect of a prolonged period of unemployment, partly due to "sobering experiences" from past recessions, which prompted the central bank and government to act accordingly. "The size of the policy response was large and was designed to insure against catastrophic economic outcomes â which it did. "A particular focus of the fiscal policy response was to keep employees attached to their jobs, even if there was little work for them during periods of lockdown. "With the benefit of hindsight, however, some argue that policymakers here and around the world took out too much insurance. "Nonetheless, it ultimately allowed us to avoid the long-term scarring effects on employment that had been a hallmark of previous recessions. "It is also possible that the particular nature of the pandemic recession â driven by health restrictions and social distancing â allowed for a faster recovery than previous recessions."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Quick response to COVID pandemic prevented soaring unemployment and 'scarred' economy

children.content: Bullock says the quick action of monetary and fiscal policy during the COVID-19 pandemic helped to minimise the worst impacts it had on the economy.
"Hundreds of thousands of Australians lost their jobs, and an equally large number were stood down or had their hours cut.
"This was a time of extreme uncertainty, with a deadly virus threatening peopleâs health and livelihoods and no vaccines in sight.
"There were credible projections that the unemployment rate would rise to 15
Â
per
Â
cent, and our own forecasts from the time had the unemployment rate remaining high for several years."

But she says Australia avoided the prospect of a prolonged period of unemployment, partly due to "sobering experiences" from past recessions, which prompted the central bank and government to act accordingly.
"The size of the policy response was large and was designed to insure against catastrophic economic outcomes â which it did.
"A particular focus of the fiscal policy response was to keep employees attached to their jobs, even if there was little work for them during periods of lockdown.
"With the benefit of hindsight, however, some argue that policymakers here and around the world took out too much insurance.
"Nonetheless, it ultimately allowed us to avoid the long-term scarring effects on employment that had been a hallmark of previous recessions.
"It is also possible that the particular nature of the pandemic recession â driven by health restrictions and social distancing â allowed for a faster recovery than previous recessions."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Deputy RBA governor Michele Bullock begins her speech telling the audience that while the central bank has been focused on combatting combat high inflation, they are still focused on its other objective â full employment. "But just because our inflation objective has been in focus recently, it does not mean that the other part of our mandate â maintaining full employment â has become any less important," she says. "Full employment is, and has always been, one of our two main objectives. "When discussing full employment, in the context of a central bankâs mandate, economists typically talk about the non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment â the NAIRU. I will come back to this concept. "But, more generally, full employment means that people who want a job can find one without having to search for too long. As I will emphasise later, the number of hours of work that people can secure is also important in defining full employment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Maintaining full employment is still RBA's focus despite inflation fight

children.content: Deputy RBA governor Michele Bullock begins her speech telling the audience that while the central bank has been focused on combatting combat high inflation, they are still focused on its other objective â full employment.
"But just because our inflation objective has been in focus recently, it does not mean that the other part of our mandate â maintaining full employment â has become any less important," she says.
"Full employment is, and has always been, one of our two main objectives.

"When discussing full employment, in the context of a central bankâs mandate, economists typically talk about the non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment â the NAIRU. I will come back to this concept.

"But, more generally, full employment means that people who want a job can find one without having to search for too long. As I will emphasise later, the number of hours of work that people can secure is also important in defining full employment."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: She's addressing the Ai Group, with a speech titled "Achieving Full Employment". She's also speaking after the RBA's minutes of its June meeting were released.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA deputy governor Michele Bullock is speaking in Newcastle

children.content: She's addressing the Ai Group, with a speech titled "Achieving Full Employment".
She's also speaking after the RBA's minutes of its June meeting were released.

image.altText: A woman squats down in a crop

title.children: Rebel Victorian Farmers Federation members call for board to be sacked as frustrations hit boiling point

image.altText: A collage of black and white images of a man smiling in a suit and tie, holding a rifle, and in a passport-style photo.

items.synopsis: The untold spy story of a mole in ASIO's ranks who sold the Soviets highly classified intelligence and got away with it.

title.children: By the time Australia's spy agency learned one of its officers was a KGB mole he was retired and playing golf

image.altText: Putin says he may seize 'buffer zone' in Ukraine

items.synopsis: Vladimir PutinÂ has a brutal new strategyÂ to ensure Russia's invasion of Ukraine is "a long process". It means there are now strategic and humanitarian imperatives for the West to defeat Putin's latest theory of victory, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Vladimir Putin's plan to win quickly in Ukraine failed. Russia is now implementing an even more brutal strategy

image.altText: A trial field of cannabis growing in Queensland.

items.synopsis: The Legalise Cannabis party says the move to reform cannabis legislation will help shift Australians out of the criminal justice system.

title.children: Bills to be introduced in three states to legalise cannabis for personal use

image.altText: Steve Smith rolls on the ground

title.children: Five quick hits â Root's unorthodox batting raises eyebrows and Bairstow lets Khawaja off

title.children: Australia and England follow different paths to meet for a thrilling climax to Edgbaston Test

image.altText: A man speaking on a podium

items.synopsis: For the first time, the Australian government will sponsor a poet to represent the country, but the details of how they will be selected remain a mystery.

image.altText: Artist Montana McStay with her artwork

title.children: Gippsland artist helping disadvantaged First Nations students learn about their culture

image.altText: A young woman with long blonde hair stands outside, wearing a white jumper and holding books unde rher arm

items.synopsis: Jasmine didnât have a parental figure to help her navigate the tax system orÂ buy household basics. But she's pleased other teens in foster care may soon have support for longer under law reform promised across the country.

title.children: After going through 'dark days' when she left foster care at 18, Jasmin is studying to become a paramedic

image.altText: A woman wearing a white turtle neck and black blazer stands smiling in a restaurant.

items.synopsis: North Korea's "Jangmadang Generation" grew up facing immense hardship after a devastating famine. NowÂ those fortunate few who escaped find the skills they used to survive rather helpful in capitalist South Korea.

title.children: Chan Yang built a thriving secret business in North Korea. Then she made a daring bid for freedom

image.altText: A split image of an elderly white man wearing a beanie, and a sepia image of a smiling young man with neat hair.

items.synopsis: Ninety-two-year-old Tom ElliotÂ waited a long timeÂ to learn more about his father Jim'sÂ involvement inÂ World War I. But with the help of his family, he has finally visited the placesÂ Jim endured horrors that he took to his grave.

title.children: 'He wasn't expected to live': WWI veteran's son retraces the steps of his father

image.altText: Women in black shirt holding flyer looks sad

title.children: Ann says lowering the bowel cancer screening age could have saved her 41yo daughter's life

image.altText: A smiling, middle-aged man with short hair, wearing a collared shirt.

items.synopsis: Morwell resident John Swiety was last seen in a rural area about four hours' drive from his home. Police have launched a fresh appeal for information and say his loved ones are "desperate for answers".

title.children: Search for missing Gippsland man continues months after suspicious disappearance

image.altText: A clothing store in Sydney advertises for staff in its shopfront.

items.synopsis: While economic growth is slowing, the jobs market hasn't been this strong since the 1950s. Unemployment is plumbing half century lows â a development that has everyone from central banks to politicians scratching their heads, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Interest rates aren't working in the way we thought they would and it's not clear why

image.altText: Greig Pickhaver aka HG Nelson wearing a navy blue collared shirt and smiling at David Wenham, who's sitting opposite him

items.synopsis: He's one half of much-loved comedy duo Roy and HG, but Greig Pickhaver says a diagnosis of dyslexia was both a "blessing and a curse" as he carved out a successful career "making up things on the spot".

title.children: Greig 'HG Nelson' Pickhaver on why planning out life is 'a complete crock'

image.altText: Man wearing black t-shirt stands on balcony with ocean in the background, folding his arms.

items.synopsis: The International Transport Workers' Federation says inspections of boats at NSW portsÂ raise serious concerns about pay and conditions.Â

title.children: Union says 'modern slavery' must end as seafarer wage crackdown finds $4 million owed to workers

image.altText: A white woman with grey hair and blue eyes looks into the camera.

items.synopsis: Set amid the sexism of the 60s, Lessons in Chemistry and its fiery protagonist haveÂ captured hearts around the world.

title.children: Bonnie Garmus got 98 rejections from book agents. Then she wrote a global bestseller

image.altText: A man in a suit is pictured walking holding his phone up to his ear, he is surrounded by big grey buildings in Beijing CBD.

items.synopsis: From cutting salaries and bonuses and asking staff not to wear expensive clothes and watches at work, to reining in travel and entertainment expenses, Chinese financial firms have jumped on an austerity drive as Beijing pushes to bridge the wealth gap.

title.children: No more flashy clothes, designer bags or five-star hotels: Chinese bankers told to rein in expenses in austerity drive

image.altText: Two players in red jerseys pose for a photo in front of an emblem.

title.children: Matildas dare to dream of Women's World Cup success after England's Euros win on home soil

title.children: 'Toxic': Shorten takes aim at behaviour of politicians in parliament

image.altText: Ukrainian soldiers hold up yellow-and-blue national flags.

items.synopsis: Ukraine says it has made another gain in its counteroffensive, drivingÂ Russian forces out of the village of Piatykhatky, which is significant for being near the most direct route to the Azov Sea coast.

title.children: Ukraine claims eight villages now retaken, with 'biggest blow' in offensive yet to come

items.synopsis: The UNÂ has adopted the world's first treaty to protect the high seas and preserve marine biodiversity in international waters, marking a milestone after nearly 20 years of effort, UNÂ Secretary-General Antonio Guterres announced Monday.

title.children: UN adopts world's first treaty to protect marine biodiversity
